author: morningstar.com
title: Dialog Semiconductor to Buy Atmel for $4.6 Billion--Update
text:
By Sarah Sloat And Robert Wall
U.K.-based chip maker Dialog Semiconductor PLC said Sunday it has agreed to buy U.S. peer Atmel Corp. for a total of $4.6 billion in cash and shares.
Dialog said both companies' boards of directors have approved the transaction, which is expected to close in the first quarter of 2016.
With the deal, Dialog said it aims to become a more influential player in the growing market for linked devices. The company said it was adding Atmel in part to gain greater scale as it vies for business in a market it estimates at $20 billion by 2019.
Dialog, spun out from Daimler-Benz AG in 2000, has grown to become a specialist in power management for smartphones and other electronic devices, and counts Apple Inc. and Lenovo as customers. It also is working on fast charging technologies. The Atmel deal is designed to add the U.S. company's expertise in microcontrollers designed to enable smartphones to control other devices
Dialog also said it was attracted to Atmel for its work on addressing emerging security concerns involved in linking multiple devices.
"Our new, enlarged company will be a diversified, high-growth market leader in mobile power, [Internet of things] and automotive," said Dialog Chief Executive Jalal Bagherli.
In the transaction, Atmel shareholders would receive $4.65 in cash and 0.112 of a Dialog American depositary share for each Atmel common share, or the equivalent of $10.42, Dialog said, based on Dialog's closing price on Friday. In Nasdaq trading, Atmel's shares fell 2.2% on Friday to $7.27.
Atmel had signaled it might be considering a sale on Aug. 24, when the company said it was extending the retirement date of Chief Executive Steven Laub through the completion of a strategic review process. Mr. Laub, who had led the company since 2006, had said in May that he would retire on Aug. 31.
The combined company would have $2.7 billion in sales and yield earnings growth for Dialog in 2017, the London-based acquirer said.
Dialog expects the transaction to result in annual savings of $150 million within two years. The company will fund the takeover with existing cash, new debt and shares.
